chunk_summary: Typhoid conjugate vaccine (TCV) is recommended in India for children from 6 months, with a single dose typically at 9–12 months. It offers longer protection than older vaccines and can be coadministered with other vaccines. Public health schedules guide implementation alongside WASH measures.
learning_objectives: Understand the role of typhoid conjugate vaccine (TCV) in preventing typhoid fever in children.
Identify the recommended age and dosing schedule for TCV in India.
Differentiate between TCV, Vi polysaccharide vaccine, and Ty21a oral vaccine in terms of efficacy and usage.
Recognize the importance of integrating immunization with WASH measures for comprehensive prevention.
key_facts: Typhoid conjugate vaccine (TCV) is recommended from 6 months of age, with a single dose typically given at 9–12 months.
TCV provides T-cell–dependent immunity and longer protection compared to Vi polysaccharide vaccines.
Vi polysaccharide vaccine is not immunogenic in children under 2 years and requires repeat dosing.
TCV can be coadministered with other routine childhood vaccines at separate sites.
Vaccination does not protect against Salmonella Paratyphi A, necessitating WASH measures.
National advisory groups (e.g., NTAGI) recommend phased public schedule implementation.
reference_quote: The preferred product for children is the typhoid conjugate vaccine (TCV), which can be given from 6 months of age and produces T-cell–dependent immunity with longer protection than older polysaccharide vaccines. (Source: IAP ACVIP guidance)
